thread.title: Robert Klein Set Up Firm to Help Lenders Protect Homes Going Through Foreclosure

author: James R. Hagerty
title: Robert Klein Set Up Firm to Help Lenders Protect Homes Going Through Foreclosure

organizations.name: help lenders protect homes going through foreclosure

text:
0 COMMENTS
Robert Klein’s father once told him: “God blessed you with a brain and cursed you with a mouth.” Working for a boss would be difficult.
So Mr. Klein, a high-school dropout, was always his own boss, starting as a New York taxi driver and later running his own fruit-and-vegetable wholesaling business in Cleveland. In 1990, he founded Safeguard Properties in the obscure business of mortgage field services. Such firms do foreclosure-related chores for lenders, including changing locks on abandoned homes, sealing broken windows and handling basic repairs so houses can be resold.
He started with one employee and grew to around 1,000 as Safeguard expanded nationwide and became one of the largest companies of its type. The surge in mortgage defaults starting around 2006 meant higher revenue but also controversy, as local officials sometimes accused lenders and their agents of blighting neighborhoods by failing to keep up with maintenance.
“Everything is not perfect,” he told the Washington Post in 2011 , but “I think we’re doing a decent job.”

Mr. Klein died May 3 in Cleveland, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65.
The polycarbonate panels sold by his SecureView company, formed about five years ago, are designed to make it harder to tell that homes are unoccupied. Windows boarded up with plywood were an invitation to vandals and squatters, he said. “Our goal is to eliminate plywood, period,” Mr. Klein told The Wall Street Journal in 2013.
Robert Klein, known to friends as Mendy, was born Oct. 16, 1952, in Hungary. His parents emigrated to the U.S. a few years later and settled in Brooklyn. His father worked for a kosher-food plant. At 16, Mr. Klein became a cabdriver, a job he kept for about five years. He then bought an uncle’s wholesale-produce business in Cleveland.
Mr. Klein said he succeeded in field services by proving himself a reliable partner for lenders. In the firm’s early days, he said in an interview with Smart Business Cleveland, a mistake by one of the firm’s contractors caused $18,000 of plumbing damages at one foreclosed home.
“We have a problem,” Mr. Klein recalled being told by his client’s chief executive.
Mr. Klein said he responded: “We don’t have a problem. I have a problem. You hired me to do the job right, and it wasn’t.” He then made sure the damages were repaired at Safeguard’s expense.
Mr. Klein helped create and finance a partnership that renovated homes in Cleveland’s Slavic Village neighborhood after it was devastated by the foreclosure wave. He also donated to numerous Jewish and other causes.
In 2010, Mr. Klein passed the CEO job at Safeguard to a son-in-law, Alan Jaffa, but remained chairman.
He is survived by his wife, Ita, four children, 20 grandchildren and one great-grandchild.
